months to minutes — increasing manufacturing competitiveness, efficiency, and turns on capital.

- User Data policy: APK REQUIRES PROMINENT DISCLOSURE

**We help everyday people to invest in the startups they love**
Wefunder is the largest funding platform connecting founders with their community to become investors. Over the past few years, we've helped fund over 1000 pre-IPO startups with $500M+, from early-stage moonshots to unicorns. In 2021, regulatory
reform put Community Rounds on the map - and since then, we’ve helped Substack, Mercury, Levels, and thousands of other startups raise money from their customers and community.  We built this space from the ground up, and now we’re looking for
someone help more founders launch a Community Round.
Wefunder's Story 💡  https://wefunder.com/wefunder
Our Public Benefit Corp Mission 🎙 https://wefunder.com/charter
**Why Wefunder**
*Note: This position is based in San Francisco.*
We’re a team of founder types. Your potential matters more than your background or experience; we’re the company where you can take your shot. Everyone is here to learn and grow, to work on a meaningful product, and to fix capitalism. We’ve spent
years lobbying congress to fix the law, and in turn, created this industry.
- 💰 Salary Range: $75,000 - 110,000 / year

Technical Product Manager at Crux (W24) ₹1.8M - ₹3M INR • Embedded AI Copilots on Structured Data Bengaluru, KA, IN Full-time 1+ years Finish profile to apply Save About Crux Crux is an AI Copilot that enables super-fast decision-making for business teams. We introduce you to the future of analytics where answers, insights, or projections are minutes away, not days - simply by asking questions in plain English. Crux was founded by a young team of IIT Bombay graduates who began their journey by building software for a range of industries while they were still in college. We went on to be associated with the brilliant teams at Bain & Co, Citibank, PwC, Johnson & Johnson, ITC, and NAVI. We are backed by supportive investors like Emergent, Y Combinator, Neon, First Cheque, and executive leaders from leading listed enterprises SaaS. Our founding team includes graduates from various top-tier engineering colleges including IIT Bombay, IIT Kharagpur, and BITS Pilani. About the role As the Technical Product Manager at Crux, you will play a pivotal role in shaping the future of our existing core product platform and features, as well as emerging product areas. You'll work closely with our internal teams - engineering, sales, design, etc. - to ensure we are building something that makes customers happy. You’ll also work closely with our current customers to understand their needs better. You will have autonomy, ownership, and impact on the platform and throughout the company Key Responsibilities: Maintain the product roadmap, requirements, and designs, collaborating with the development team on prioritization Interaction with customers Tasked with identifying the core of a user problem and designing experiences to solve it Continuous communication with our customers to gather feedback and to make data-driven decisions related to product iteration Collaboration with the Engineering Team Lead and Develop the product roadmap along with the engineering team, ensuring it aligns with the company's long-term goals and vision. Monitor and analyze product performance against requirements/success metrics Collaboration With the Design Team Facilitate collaborative brainstorming sessions with the design team to conceptualize new features or improvements based on user feedback and market research. Quickly build wireframes related to changes/new features in the product for the design teams to build prototypes out of. Regularly review and provide constructive feedback on design prototypes, ensuring they meet the product's vision, goals, and user needs Lead product vision strategy & execution Drive the execution of product development projects, ensuring that they are delivered on time and within scope Define clear product requirements and success metrics, effectively communicating requirements in user stories with well-defined acceptance criteria Identify, pursue, and develop new product opportunities Stay ahead of industry trends to proactively identify potential new products Technology We are building next-gen AI assistants for data teams. Working on cutting-edge LLMs to optimise their usage on a variety of use cases controlling their accuracy and hallucinations. Interview Process At Crux, we are looking for individuals who enjoy iterating & shipping quickly, are passionate about solving hard problems and are eager to learn. Someone who demonstrates a strong sense of ownership and autonomy. Round 1: Initial Screening Round This stage is a more informal call to get to know more about the role, and for you to evaluate whether it’s a good fit for you. We are looking for people with a strong interest in startups and the motivation to help them; this is usually exhibited by past experience working at or starting one yourself. Lastly, the conversation will also cover some light discussion about your past projects. Round 2/3: Product-Thinking Rounds This stage will be a more technical deep dive where you shall be given a problem statement on-spot or in advance. This problem statement will most probably be something our team is facing as we speak so you may be expected to try your hands on the product and come up with practical solutions. Round 3/4: Culture Fit For the “fit” portion, we are again looking for ownership and autonomy, but we also dig deeper into communication. This is evaluated throughout the process -- in how you communicate your approach, solutions, and overall thinking. Each interview is 1 hour long, with 45 minutes allocated for the technical deep-dive, and 15 minutes for general Q&A.

> *Jack P.*  [4:39 PM]
> <@UQJKZU8RW> do you see all the entries in the  electrify buildings section of your RfS fitting into the venture backed bucket? / do you see founders trying to find business models to appease VC that are unrealistic for the market?
I think a lot of things you can build are venture fundable. The main reason is the market is so large. To give an example, there are 80 million single family homes. They change their heating system every ~20 years if not more often. That means 4M heating systems changed per year. At say $5k per upgrade that is a $20B annual market - in just heating systems. Lets say its $10k per upgrade, thats $40B. HUGE markets. The best ideas are software only ideas that accelerate green transitions on this market. Something like Aurora Solar for example. But also things like <https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=35138319>. Sometimes you have to do the hardware but often you don’t have to touch hardware. Given how extremely basic many of the functions of just local installers/contractors are - from price transparency, to payment to scheduling etc - there is huge amount of opportunity in just that area. but this applies to everything in homes, stoves, ev chargers, water heaters etc

PPAs can be better, but often PPAs are used for REC arbitrage, where the RECs from the PPA are sold into a state RPS market and then replaced by cheaper, unbundled RECs from a non-RPS state. It really comes down to carbon accounting. You can do this the right way, or the wrong way. Both are possible under current protocols, but only one moves the needle on emissions reductions.

My take is that we need to be doing honest emissions accounting, which means that the REC and the PPA can both be viable pathways to net-zero, but neither are sufficient by themselves. Whatever attribute is being claimed needs to be matched on an hourly basis to the emissions intensity of the grid that it feeds into, the same way that consumption that is being netted out should be matched to hourly emissions intensity.

Hey Peter, great question.

Being a non-profit allows us to focus on building only the highest carbon impact per dollar solar projects possible. These are solar facilities that institutional and high net worth investors won’t fund, often simply because there is a fear a stigma about deploying innovative infrastructure in emerging markets. The yield on these investments are not enough to be compelling to any type of scalable capital.

However, since <http://Renewables.org|Renewables.org>’s customers lend us funds at 0% and we lend it to developers at ~2-6%, we can earn a yield healthy enough to power user acquisition and product development. If we were a for-profit, we’d have to pass the majority of the yield to the user, file as a regulation crowdfunding portal or regulation A security with the SEC (very costly), and market in a much more crowded space (alternative investments) with a much smaller budget.

Using the Kiva model that cofounder Premal Shah developed allows us to build a far more resilient business at a small scale and stay aligned with the customer — rather than chipping away at their meager return with fees. Kiva managed to build two new finance verticals around which major ecosystems now exists (micro finance and online crowdfunding) — and now we hope to do the same with emerging market solar.

I actually attempted to make a for-profit online solar investing platform which invested in domestic C&I solar projects called <http://www.Legends.Solar|www.Legends.Solar>. Learned all this the hard way!

On solutions... I think we should expect to see increased valuations for any company of any kind that is building products in a space with significant tailwinds. So here again it is probably important to narrow the field of view and extract carbon out of the question for a minute. For instance, for lots of reasons (including decarbonization needs) renewable energy penetration on the grid will be growing. That will be matched with increasing software monitoring, modeling, and management of grid systems. So I don't think it is crazy to imagine higher valuations for companies building solutions in that space - irrespective of any carbon ambitions.
